original_data.question: A 21-year-old man with a past medical history significant for Down syndrome presents to the outpatient primary care clinic for a routine follow up and high risk screening. He is relatively high functioning and currently has no additional significant medical conditions. He feels well and a physical examination shows that he is within normal limits. He denies any current tobacco use, alcohol use, or illicit drug use. His vital signs include: temperature, 36.7°C (98.0°F); blood pressure, 126/74 mm Hg; heart rate, 87/min; and respiratory rate, 17/min. When considering possible conditions for which this patient is predisposed, which of the following neoplasms is associated with Down syndrome?

model_response:
The correct answer is B (Astrocytoma and cardiac rhabdomyoma). Children with Down syndrome are predisposed to the development of certain tumors. The most common tumors in children with Down syndrome are juvenile type of astrocytoma and cardiac rhabdomyoma. Other tumors that occur with increased frequency in children with Down syndrome include acute lymphoblastic leukemia, lymphoblastic lymphoma, and hepatoblastoma. Gastric adenocarcinoma is more common in individuals with trisomy 21 who have a maternal inheritance of the Barrett esophagus. Esophageal adenocarcinoma is more common in individuals with trisomy 21 who have a paternal inheritance of the Barrett esophagus.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

A chromosome disorder associated either with an extra CHROMOSOME 21 or an effective TRISOMY for chromosome 21. Clinical manifestations include HYPOTONIA, short stature, BRACHYCEPHALY, upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthus, Brushfield spots on the iris, protruding tongue, small ears, short, broad hands, fifth finger clinodactyly, single transverse palmar crease, and moderate to severe INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY. Cardiac and gastrointestinal malformations, a marked increase in the incidence of LEUKEMIA, and the early onset of ALZHEIMER DISEASE are also associated with this condition. Pathologic features include the development of NEUROFIBRILLARY TANGLES in neurons and the deposition of AMYLOID BETA-PROTEIN, similar to the pathology of ALZHEIMER DISEASE. (Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p213)
Persons who receive ambulatory care at an outpatient department or clinic without room and board being provided.
Procedures performed on people to identify those who have NEOPLASMS or PRENEOPLASTIC CONDITIONS.
Any kind of illness or circumstance which requires medical monitoring.
Emotional sensations.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Use of TOBACCO (Nicotiana tabacum L) and TOBACCO PRODUCTS.
Behaviors associated with the ingesting of ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES, including social drinking.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
Joined in some kind of relationship.
